reviewText: Murder on the Orient Express, 2010 filmWe see scenes in Istanbul. A mob of people attack a woman and stone her. [This new scene does not understand that society.] Mr. Poirot will travel to London on the Calais Express. Other passengers arrive. The steam train leaves the station. [This shows train travel in olden times.] We meet the other passengers in the dining car. One man, Ratchett, asks Poirot to protect him (a rich man has enemies). In the night Poirot is awakened by a scream. Then the train makes an stop because of the snow drifts. Poirot is summoned, there is a dead man in one cabin. Stabbed fifteen times in a frenzy. This coach will be kept isolated. The murderer is on the train! Poirot diagnoses the stab wounds (both a right and left hand) and other clues left by the body (a lady's handkerchief has an embroidered `H'). The passengers are gathered in the dining car. [To hear other people's testimony?] The attendant Michel tells what he saw. Poirot questions the other passengers. He identifies Ratchett - the kidnapper of a young girl who died. [A fictionalized version of the Lindbergh kidnapping.]We learn of a link to this crime for Ratchett's servant McQueen. Poirot questions the other passengers about their connection to America and the Armstrong family. The maid of a lady tells what she saw at night. A Colonel tells his story. Poirot questions the other passengers and learns of their connections to the Armstrong family. These twelve people match the twelve wounds! Poirot has made an amazing deduction again. The people admit to their crime. Should they have taken the law into their own hands? What will Poirot do? Or the other people? A whistle announces the arrival of the rescue train. "Do what is right"? Poirot prays for guidance, then talks to the Yugoslav police. [The ending is deliberately obscure. Poirot opined the murderer dressed as a train conductor, stabbed Ratchett, then got off at the last stop. Justice is served if not the law.] Avoid this version! I dislike newer versions of old classic stories that have been changed to distort the original story. There was a better version filmed in the early 1970s; it is true to the book. The book is better than the movie. It is a good story, but the synchronized murder seems implausible.Raymond Chandler criticized those murder mysteries concocted so the author could provide a clever solution ("The Simple Art of Murder"). Yet Agatha Christie's murder mysteries remain popular and available in public libraries while the courtroom dramas of Erle Stanley Gardner are mostly unavailable. Gardner and others formed "The Court of Last Resort" to defend the innocent convicted. Many of his novels may remind you of a famous case in the 1920s where two men were convicted and executed due to mistaken identification. How many other convictions were based on mistaken identification? The Innocence Project regularly frees convicted men after DNA evidence proves their innocence. [I resent Christie's assumption that a kidnapper of a child could be freed by pressure on the American legal system.]

reviewText: I can see why a lot of people were unhappy with AGATHA CHRISTIE'S POIROT: MURDER ON THE ORIENT EXPRESS (Blu-Ray), especially if they're a fan of the "Poirot" series, because actor David Suchet's characterization of the venerable Belgian detective is practically 180-degrees from the charming, elegant fop us fans have become accustomed to. In MURDER ON THE ORIENT EXPRESS, Suchet's "Poirot" character is a conflicted, non-smiling -- almost cantankerous -- senior, which is what really turned a lot of reviewers off.Even though I was at first taken aback by this portrayal, it only convinced me of the great acting talents of David Suchet. Really, if you're used to seeingAgatha Christie's Poirot: Series 1 [Blu-ray], then it's like watching two different characters entirely. Now I'm only up toPoirot: Series Three [Blu-ray] on that show so I don't know if Suchet's characterization becomes more hard-nosed toward the later series but it really is quite different here.Nevertheless, the movie itself is still gripping, even though I also own the 1974Agatha Christie's Murder on the Orient Express, which is the Albert Finney version, so I know how the story ends. It's still a masterpiece of storytelling centering on justice, revenge, morality, and conflicting ideals between right and wrong.For those that are unfamiliar with the story, Poirot gets called back to his office from Istanbul, and by luck, he gets on the "Orient Express." While riding the train, a passenger gets murdered, and then the train gets stuck in the middle of nowhere when snow covers the tracks, and so it's up to Poirot to figure out who the murderer is. In this case, the answer is not a simple one. I haven't read the book, so I don't know how close or how far the story goes from its source, but I can say that in comparison to the 1974 movie this one leaves no mistake of what happens in the end.Anyway, I enjoyed it even though Suchet's portrayal was almost nasty, but perhaps the opening of the movie explains why Poirot was so bitter. Maybe bitter isn't the right word, but deeply conflicted, which shows up in Suchet's characterization, is a better way to explain it.The Blu-Ray's picture does have some snow/noise in the darker scenes, but nothing that really interferes with viewing pleasure.Even though most fans might be disappointed with this characterization, the real gem on here is the documentary called, "David Suchet on the Orient Express." Here the wonderful (and genial) actor actually takes the viewer on the road with him as he goes on the real Orient Express from London and then on to Venice and finally Prague.***  SPECIAL FEATURES  **** "David Suchet on the Orient Express" *(2009) - 47-minutes:01-secondFollow the actor as he goes on board the real Orient Express, going from the UK to Venice to Prague. You get to see the compartments, the dining car/bar, the porters, and there's wonderful historic footage included as well, and Suchet interviews the train's experts and passengers on board the iconic train. Suchet even gets to drive the Orient Express on one stretch of track. And you also get to see some beautiful scenes of Venice as David gets to spend some sight seeing time on a quick stop before heading off to Prague.* "120 Anniversary of Agatha Christie's Birth" (2010) - TextThis details the celebrations around the world honoring the works of Agatha Christie.* "Poirot Books" - Text (scrolls up and lists title and year published)Anyway, the documentary makes this worthy of being in the library. As long as you aren't stuck on seeing David Suchet's normal portrayal of "Hercule Poirot" then I think you'll enjoy the movie, too. Just be prepared.

reviewText: In a word: dark. Many of the negative reviews that I've seen regarding this film are correct in two things: 1) The screenwriters have taken liberties. This happens in screen adaptations, but if you're a fan of the book I'd understand some consternation. 2) In tone, this is unlike the original Poirot television series (and early movies), which relied more on the charms of its cast and the mannerisms of its lead than it did complexity of character or originality of plot. (Let's be honest: delightful as they were, after a few TV episodes and Poirot novels, Christie's formula began to show). This movie, however, has no Hastings, Ms. Lemmon, or Japp (even Ariadne Oliver, the fill-in friend inserted into a few of the more recent movies, is missing), and Poirot's mannerisms have been toned down. And while it's true that Hastings, et al, weren't in the novel, one could argue that if the screenwriters were determined to make changes, they could have thrown in one of Poirot's old buddies.But now, a caveat: though I enjoyed the old TV show, I often found the characterizations to be... formulaic. Charming, certainly, but formulaic; the characters never evolved. But that's a matter of personal taste, and I know some loved the show for that reason (for its charm). However, I found that lack of evolution to be wanting, and so I like the notion of deepening Poirot's character. Poirot has been exposed to some nasty things, and a darkening world view would be a natural result. Suchet, a fine actor, ably conveys this loss of optimism. Here, he is also in shock over the consequences of his decisions on an earlier case (the violent end of which is seen at the very beginning), and the events of this film further strain his worldview. The whole of the events in the first five minutes, for example, is new material that may stun fans of the more sedate TV show, but its integral to what follows - which is a morality play about the natures of justice and vengeance. So a warning: this isn't cinematic comfort food.Other bonuses: the rest of the cast ranges from the solid to the very good, and the film is beautifully filmed (production values are clearly higher here than they were on the old show).  The musical score is also well played.

reviewText: This is a refreshing - yet confusing - adventure for the intrepid David Suchet, our favorite Poirot interpreter (notwithstanding Albert Finney, and this is not your grandfather's MURDER ON THE ORIENT EXPRESS).Skipping over most of the other actors, who are frankly rather irritating and cardboard here, Suchet's Poirot boards the Orient Express in a rather sour, dour old mood reminiscent of people on their way into the nursing home. Poirot has been summoned from his trip to Palestine back to London after a break in a pending case. He is taking, what else, the Orient Express back home.Earlier in Istanbul, Poirot witnesses the stoning of an adulterous woman by her husband, and it explains, I suppose, Poirot's rather foul mood on the train. I don't think the influence of HARRY POTTER helped much here, but it added a chilling atmosphere to the murder mystery - I loved the portrayal of the Express stuck in the snow with its power gone.The entire film, therefore, is dark, creepily quiet and ominous. This is offset (I hate to beat a dead horse) by Poirot's morose and grouchy presence. Also, for some reason, Suchet was terribly aged for this outing as Poirot, and he looks like the Hush Puppies Bassett Hound. If memory serves (and it never does) Poirot is supposed to be nearing age 60 when this story takes place - around Suchet's real age. As I recall, Christie published the original novel sometime around 1933.As I said, this film has its qualities and I love the streamlining of the story, though it then becomes a raging torrent of confusion. Frankly the direction is very bad; it's the total opposite of the brilliant APPOINTMENT WITH DEATH (which was shot only a year earlier). However, the direction itself cannot ruin this. It was also dirty pool stealing Sydney Lumet's original idea of flashing the newspaper headlines regarding Daisy Armstrong's murder.Finally, kudos to the incredibly versatile Toby Jones (he plays the vicious, evil Ratchet/Franco Cassetti much better than Richard Widmark did in Lumet's movie). Jones shot from one star to the next - from doing the voice of Dobby on HARRY POTTER to facing off against Phillip Seymour Hoffman, in their famous duel portraying Truman Capote (Jones' INFAMOUS lost to Hoffman's multi-Oscar CAPOTE). And I love the way this film clearly explains what Cassetti is actually doing on this trip - and how his very presence figures into the plan.I have to say I love seeing Suchet still at it, with new films in the offing. He's already completed THE THIRD GIRL and DEATH ON THE NILE (though I've only seen an unidentified teaser for the latter on "PBS Mystery!"). The wife and I have been enjoying Suchet since he began playing Poirot on the A&E; channel back in the 1980s. Rumor mills are untrustworthy, but I have heard that Suchet looks forward to filming CURTAIN, the last Poirot story, in which we find an eighty-something Poirot confined to a wheelchair. In that final tale, Poirot dies.If you can, grab the ACORN edition of this dvd: it includes Suchet's APPOINTMENT WITH DEATH (one of my favorite of Suchet's realizations), some notes on Suchet's history playing Poirot, and it is inexpensive. Don't expect to find that edition here at Amazon.This disc is offered with the extra of David Suchet's 48-minute documentary on the modern Orient Express, which is a delight and very informative. This version and Lumet's: they make a good team, and this is a not totally unpleasant break from Lumet's classic film.
summary: "Shall I tell you what I know?"

reviewText: Quelle dommage! At long last, David Suchet, the best onscreen Poirot of all time, gets a chance with the famous "Murder On the Orient Express" but.. what is this? The screenplay writer and the director have decided that this cracking mystery ought to be treated like the darkest, heaviest thing ever written. Sigh. Oh dear oh dear. (Something similar was done to the great Jeremy Brett in his later years Sherlock Holmes films.) Thus we have Poirot, made up to look much older and with dark circles under his eyes, ranting and raving even more than Albert Finney and praying like a medieval pilgrim and suffering torturedly over moral dilemmas in the eyes of God (none of which is really in the book.) Um... hmm. Interesting attempt at doing something different, I guess, but then again we don't really need something different in this case. Darn, it coulda been a layup... all they had to do was be true to the book and the character like they usually do, and Suchet's version would have been the best. Instead, they went wildly off track and we get this dim mess which starts with a soldier blowing his brains out in Poirot's face and ends with the great sleuth sobbing on a railway platform in the cold gray light of dawn. What a bummer, and needlessly so. I suppose all murder mysteries have a grim premise, but that certainly isn't what makes them fun; it's the detection and the suspects and the clues and, well, the likeable detective. Not here. (True, the chilling atmosphere of the train stuck in the snow is certainly well done. Perhaps overdone.) Maybe if they had pared this one down to an hour they wouldn't have felt compelled to pad it with all this sniveling in the final act. Fortunately, they seem to have singled this particular mystery out for such treatement, and other recent films with Suchet in them do not suffer from quite this heavy handed a gloom.

reviewText: An outrageously poor adaptation on many levels, I am saddened to think what a complete travesty this was to Agatha Christie, the series which has in years past epitomized her books, and to David Suchet, who has otherwise faithfully portrayed Poirot with remarkable skill. It was not simply that this was not faithful to one of the greatest mystery classics ever written, or that the director obviously fancied himself more innovative than the author with his lame duck attempts at modernizing the script; if those were the only issues, I believe the cast could have redeemed this. But the deeper character motivations suffered too gravely under the weight of these changes.Here we have a Poirot who is so so bitter and angry it actually detracts - and was distracting - from his depiction. His cynicism was frankly off putting to the point I could not even concentrate on the mystery. So, even had these "improvements" added to the script, Poirot himself was, in my opinion, intolerable to watch.Every iota of intelligence, suspense or enjoyment was wrung out of this by the acting and unwarranted changes. It was nothing more than sensationalistic rubbish, more resembling something I should expect to see from a dumbed down Hollywood gem than anything based on classic British literature. Avoid this one at all costs. The 1979 movie remains the far better option.

reviewText: By: RevitMurder on the Orient Express is one of Dame Agatha Christie's greatest mysteries. Most of us who are fans of this author have gotten to know the preferences, intentions, and feelings she conveys in her stories. We know that she wants to entertain her readers and wants everybody to be happy. She decries lying, cheating and most of all murder. She values justice but views it as being a little different from a literal interpretation of the law. It is proper that producers and actors making films based on her stories are respectful and follow her preferences. When the excellent film Murder on the Orient Express staring Albert Finney as Poirot with an all star cast was released in 1974 we were all delighted with it. The book the movie was based on ends when Poirot who had just related two solutions for the murder of Ratchett to the assembled travelers in the Calais Coach has asked the Director of the Orient Express Line to select one of the solutions and present it to the Jugo-Slavian police when they arrive. At that point Poirot says "having placed my solutions before you I have the honour to retire from the case..." Thus Agatha Christie had succeeded in getting her favorite detective out of the case without presenting any un-factual information to the police.  As we know Hollywood prefers an ending that complies with the law so in the film the selected solution is placed before the police.When a remake of the movie was made in 2013 with David Suchet in the staring role, some of us were surprised with the outcome. It was a major rewrite that has a slightly different approach than Agatha Christie's masterpiece. One might even conjecture that Agatha Christie would not have liked the remake at all; but she may have loved it. It includes a few newly written segments that were not part of the original book and in my view would probably never have been written by Agatha Christie. At the beginning of the film there was a several minute scene in Syria where Poirot repeatedly and aggressively accused a distinguished young officer of lying to him to the point of causing the young man to draw his pistol and shoot himself in front of his superior officer, his friends and Poirot. The officer who was assigned to see Poirot off to the boat that would take him to Istanbul timidly slipped a comment in at the end of his carefully prepared speech to the effect that he didn't think the young officer who shot himself should have had to pay such a heavy price for one small mistake.There was a fairly long series of scenes in the back streets of Istanbul in view of Sainte Sophia where Poirot saw a young couple who saw a crowd of people descend on a young girl, who had been accused of adultery by her husband, spit on her and stone her to death. When Poirot boarded the Orient Express he saw the young woman who had witnessed the stoning. When she began to express compassion for the girl who had been killed, Poirot responded saying that the girl had to suffer a violent death because it was the penalty for what she had done under the law she knew and lived by.For many years we have been spoiled with Suchet's brilliant interpretations of Hercule Poirot. We loved all of the early episodes when he lived in a marvelous Art Deco apartment house and had Miss Lemon, Captain Hastings and Chief Inspector Japp to keep the cases running smoothly. When his Art Deco apartment was replaced by a smaller apartment with warm brown mahogany paneling, and Captain Hastings and Miss Lemon had faded away to be replaced by a gentleman's gentleman, Poirot grew a little less tolerant of the cheats, liars and murderers. Still he remained a gentleman and focused on apprehending wrong doers. In this most recent 2013 version of Murder on the Orient Express, he has changed a lot. He has become a little cranky and a more demanding old man who insists on the law being obeyed. His focus has shifted to include more religion and he holds the blind goddess of justice and law high above everything else. The end of the movie took place in the Calais Coach of the train with all of the passengers locked in the dining car. The electricity was out, and at night it was dark and cold. The atmosphere was foreboding. Poirot insisted that those who had stabbed Ratchett were guilty of murder; he spent a sleepless night. When the tracks were cleared of snow, the police arrived and the sun came up shining Poirot re-evaluated the situation. With his conscience tearing at his heart he presented the conductors uniform to the police telling them of an unidentified man, probably Mafia related, who had boarded the train at a station, murdered Ratchett, and left the train in the night at another station. Poirot retreated in silent tears.I did not enjoy it the first time I saw it; I do not agree with the way the original story has been changed, If you read Curtain: Poirot's Last case you will understand that Poirot does not develop in the way depicted in this movie. But there is a lot to be said for holding justice and the law up high.

reviewText: There is a direct correlation between the audacity of Poirot's mustache and the quality of Suchet's performances in this series.  In this movie, it is a sad, tired looking thing, and that perfectly describes his performance here.  In fact, several of his later works lack the intensity and flamboyance present in his early work that made his character so popular. Over time, you can see how drab his mustache has grown as well.The whole cast seems to follow Suchet's lead, delivering lifeless performances in a stale atmosphere.  It's as if the ending was a foregone conclusion. There is no tension over the murder, no background buzz about the gaiety and thrill of the adventure from riding the fabulously exotic, luxurious and perhaps slightly decadent Orient Express. The location is completely wasted. They might as well have filmed this on a public transit bus.Trivia:Did you know Suchet played a role in a Poirot movie starring Peter Ustinov?  He played Inspector Japp in the movie Thirteen for Dinner.

reviewText: I received this as a gift. I understand creative license but this film abused it, resulting in a dismal remake of a story AC originally wrote as more lighthearted. I like David Suchet as Poirot but he is not so enjoyable in this version. Albert Finney and Peter Ustinov were also great Poirots, and Finney's version of this title was so much more fun. I did like Eileen Atkins as the princess, espeically when she explained to Rachett why he must die. The stoning scene at the beginning seemed to fit in with the storyline because it set the tone. Rearranging some ideas seemed ludicrous, for example, attributing the idea of the revenge to Mary Debenham instead of Mrs. Hubbard. As if the governess had more reason to seek revenge than the mother/grandmother?!? Rachett's character seemed a little too ghoulish. Richard Widmark did a much better job balancing the animal savage with the new rich crass American. Pierre Michel was too obsequious and lacking in confidence. I gave this a 2 rating for the very good performances of Barbara Hershey and Eileen Atkins.Update 11/30/13: I went back and read the original story. Mr. Hubbard does attribute the idea of this revenge to Mary D. She and McQueen did the most work on the project, funded by Mrs. Hubbard's money.
